awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Hodge Theory and D-Modules in Algebraic Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This project involves both research in pure mathematics and the mathematics training of science majors. Broadly speaking, the research component of the project is research is algebraic geometry, which is the study of study of solution sets of systems of polynomial equations. More specifically, the PI will use methods from the theory of mixed Hodge modules to solve problems in Hodge theory and algebraic geometry. The cohomology groups of a complex algebraic variety carry mixed Hodge structures, and Hodge theory studies these structures and their interaction with the geometry of the variety. The theory of mixed Hodge modules provides a modern framework for this, using the language of perverse sheaves and D-modules. The main educational component of the project is to improve the teaching of mathematics to undergraduate students pursuing a major in a non-mathematics STEM field. The PI will design and teach, in consultation with faculty from another department, a new two-semester course that meets the current mathematical needs of their students. The course will have a non-traditional format, based on an "active learning" model of instruction. In addition, the PI and co-authors will complete a book about mixed Hodge modules, that will make this powerful theory accessible to non-experts.
 
In more technical language, this project has the following research objectives: (1) to construct compactifications for images of period mappings by using the theory of limit Hodge classes; (2) to prove several instances of a conjecture about the structure of Fourier-Mukai transforms of holonomic D-modules on complex abelian varieties; (3) to simplify the construction of singular hermitian metrics on direct images of pluricanonical bundles, due to Paun and Takayama, as well as the recent proof of Ueno's conjecture by Cao and Paun.

por.por_cntn:
During the five plus one years of the grant, I worked on several problems in complex algebraic geometry and published a total of eleven papers. The most important one, joint with Stefan Kebekus, solves the "extension problem" for holomorphic forms: under what conditions do holomorphic differential forms defined on the regular locus of a space extend to a resolution of singularities? Greb, Kebekus, Kovacs, and Peternell famously proved that all forms on algebraic varieties with at worst klt singularities extend. At the time, this was thought to be a special feature of the class of singularities from the Minimal Model Program. But Kebekus and I showed that the extension problem actually has nothing to do with the Minimal Model Program: the optimal result is that if forms of a given degree extend, then forms of lower degree automatically extend as well.

In another paper, joint with Christopher Hacon and Mihnea Popa, I gave a simplified proof for the Iitaka conjecture over abelian varieties. In the original proof by Cao and Paun, the main input from complex analysis is the construction of certain singular hermitian metrics on direct images of relative pluricanonical bundles. We wrote our paper partly in order to help the algebraic geometry community understand these new techniques. We also presented a new construction of singular hermitian metrics (on adjoint bundles), based on the L2-extension theorem of Ohsawa-Takegoshi, that needs fewer assumptions than the original one. As a result, our paper is frequently cited by people in complex analysis who work on singular hermitian metrics and positivity notions for vector bundles.

My best recent result is joint with Benjamin Bakker, Thomas Grimm, and Jacob Tsimerman. We generalize the famous theorem of Cattani, Deligne, and Kaplan about the locus of Hodge classes to self-dual classes, and in the process, prove some finiteness conjectures in string theory. Unlike Hodge classes, self-dual classes do not seem to have a good geometric interpretation; and while the result by Cattani, Deligne, and Kaplan was predicted by the Hodge conjecture, our result about self-dual classes is completely unexpected from a geometric perspective.

I also did a lot of other things besides research. Together with Claude Sabbah, I started the “Mixed Hodge Module Project”, whose goal is to produce an accessible treatment of the theory of mixed Hodge modules with complex coecients. The current version of our notes, several hundred pages in total, is available online. I also did a lot of work setting up and running activities for the training and mentoring of graduate students and postdocs in our department. I co-organized a graduate summer school on algebraic groups; three large “Math Day” events for undergraduates from the New York area; a science communication workshop for postdocs at the Alda Center; and two installments of the AGNES conference series (one of them online). I have also advised four graduate students, two of whom have already graduated.
